ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Review of concepts covered in Italian 110 and 120.
This class re-teaches a lot of information from L1 and L2 in a more cultural and explanatory way. There is a strong emphasis on grammar.
I improved (hopefully) my knowledge of both the Italian language and culture.
Became more confident with speaking Italian

The class is functionally a review of L1/2 grammar with some new vocab knitted in. More specifically, that is Immagina chapters 1-6, which is more or less the overwhelming majority of content in L1 and L2. It is nice as you get to cover the content you learned piece-by-piece in L1/2 altogether. e.g. when you review object pronouns you cover them in relation to all of the structures in L1 and L2.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was great at fostering engagement with not just the language, but also Italian culture by the use of async days and discussing films, arts, and other cultural events.

Engaging discussions in class and helpful feedback on assessments were two notable strengths of this course, in addition to Professor Pellegrino being incredibly thoughtful in how she applies what we learn in our textbook to readings, exercises, and assessments.
Loved the asynchronous element, a much needed rest day. Language can be tiring
Really like Deborah she was very nice and let us have fun while making us be friends with everyone.

As the journalist David Finkel once said, "you can gift wrap a piece of **** and it's still a piece of ****" - that is, I don't think this course is particularly bad, I just don't enjoy learning Italian. That being said, I would appreciate not having a significant portion of my grade determined by a final, especially given that many/most languages at Yale do not even have a final at all, instead opting for presentations, projects, etc.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! The Italian department as a whole is incredible and the profs really want to get to know every student. I have learned so much in the few semesters I have taken it.
Yes, to students who are looking to fulfill their language requirement and especially to those interested in Italy or the history of European culture or art.
Yes I absolutely would recommend this course to any student interested in learning Italian because I feel as though my understanding of the language improved throughout the semester.
Sure, L3 was the least stressful of the three semesters of Italian, and Deborah is fantastic
Yes if you want to learn Italian

Taking Italian was easily the biggest mistake I have made academically at Yale, and possibly within the last decade. I haven't enjoyed any second of it, aside from the post-exam drinks. But this is L3, and maybe you, the reader, enjoy Italian, and if you do, this class will probably be a continuation of that enjoyment. Not much changes, essentially. 

Personally, though, I am happy I do not have to open vhlcentral.com ever again, and I am happy to not spend any more of my time learning a language defined by a falling number of speakers and attached to a nation-state that is failing. That might be a reason to learn it for the romantics reading this, just don't expect it to have any economic relevance or for it to help you in the future - may I suggest Mandarin or Spanish for that? Or maybe ASL. That shit is pretty cool.
